newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Former HK judge declares bid for post-97 chief.
newsitem.headline: Former HK judge declares bid for post-97 chief.

text.p: A senior former Hong Kong judge announced on Tuesday he would bid to become leader of the territory when the British leave next year.
Former Appeal Court Judge Simon Li called a news conference for Wednesday and said he would outline his plans then.
His very brief written statement gave no further details.

Li is the sixth prominent Hong Kong citizen to make a bid for the job of Chief Executive to take over the helm from Governor Chris Patten when the British colony reverts to China at midnight on June 30, 1997, a date now 252 days away.
Hong Kong's outgoing chief justice Sir Ti Liang Yang, shipping tycoon Tung Chee-hwa, and businessman, Peter Woo, have also declared an interest in the job.
Two self-declared candidates, a solicitor and another former High Court judge, withdrew their bids last week.

Hong Kong's first post-colonial leader will be picked by a Beijing-controlled 400-strong selection board chosen by the Preparatory Committee responsible for overseeing the transition of Hong Kong from British colony to Chinese Special Administrative Region (SAR).
Both Li and Tung are Preparatory Committee vice chairmen.
